inlineContent.text: This guide will show you how to create, use, and test a custom rule.
All validation rules in ValidatorCore conform to the IValidationRule protocol. It requires specifying the input type and implementing a validate function.

content.text: Step 3: Combining Custom and Built-in Rules

inlineContent.text: You can combine custom rules with built-in rules for more complex validation logic:

code: LengthValidationRule(min: 8, max: 20, error: "Password must be 8-20 characters"),
ContainsDigitRule(error: "Password must contain at least one number")
let result = validator.validate(input: password, rules: rules)

inlineContent.text: Explanation:
Each rule validates one specific aspect of the input (e.g., non-empty, length, contains a digit).
The Validator applies each rule independently.
This approach keeps rules focused, reusable, and simple, while Validator handles iterating through multiple rules.
You can freely mix custom and built-in rules to create comprehensive validation logic without combining rules inside the rules themselves.
Keep rules focused – one rule should check one condition.
Provide meaningful error messages – users should understand why input is invalid.
Unit test your rules – write tests to ensure correct behavior under different input scenarios.
Reuse rules – if a rule is useful in multiple places, keep it generic and reusable.
Experiment by creating rules for emails, passwords, usernames, or any custom format.

abstract.text: ValidatorCore is designed to be extensible. If the built-in validation rules do not meet your needs, you can create custom validation rules tailored to your application.
A guide to installing the Validator package into your Swift project using Swift Package Manager.

This guide will walk you through the basics of using ValidatorCore for input validation. By the end, you’ll know how to validate common input types like strings and numbers, handle validation results, and get started with custom rules.
